abstracts.cdata!:
The project's overall outcome is
            viewed as satisfactory. The lessons learned are: a) simple
            and realistic project design is required; b) the capacity of
            staff for project implementation should be evaluated and
            training should be given before project implementation; c)
            weak capacity in procurement and delay in fund and budget
            disbursement delayed project implementation; d)
            decentralization of project implementation to the provincial
            can be successful, provided that all parties are flexible in
            adjusting targets in line with institutional capacity; e)
            agreement on the responsibilities of implementation agencies
            and co-financiers should be reached before project start-up,
            and joint supervision missions should be fielded; f)
            sufficient time should be allotted under the participatory
            approach for project preparation and design; g) agricultural
            projects should continue to be designed in a holistic
            manner; h) training programs and on-the-job training are
            essential elements for achieving good results; i) it is
            risky not to make specific, credible arrangements for the
            maintenance of gravel roads as an integral part of a road
            construction project; j) design and technical specification
            should be prepared by adequately qualified professional; and
            k) it is essential that farm inputs are available at the
            right time, if improved farm practices are to be taken up
            and sustained.

18149846.projn: LA-Upland Agric. Dev. -- P004195,LA-Upland Agric. Dev. -- P004195
18149846.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific
18149846.subsc: Crops,Research,m,Agricultural extension and research,Water supply,Water supply,Roads and highways,Irrigation and drainage,Irrigation and drainage,Crops
18149846.theme: Rural markets,Land administration and management,Land administration and management,Rural services and infrastructure,Rural services and infrastructure,Rural markets
18149846.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management

abstracts.cdata!:
The project would reduce rural poverty,
            expand export earnings and improve food security, control
            soil erosion and strengthen key agricultural institutions.
            It would cover Champassak, Saravane and Sekong Provinces on
            the Bolovens Plateau in the south and Vientiane Municipality
            and Province in the north. Project activities would
            concentrate on upland cropping systems with the exception of
            irrigation rehabilitation in valley floors in Vientiane
            Province. Specifically, the project would support: (a)
            upland crop production, mainly of coffee, soybeans and other
            cash crops, and valley floor irrigated production of rice
            and other cash crops, through the provision of equipment,
            inputs and support services, and the development and
            transfer of improved and environmentally safe crop
            production technologies; (b) rehabilitation of existing
            small scale gravity irrigation schemes and establishment of
            pilot irrigation operations and maintenance (O&M)
            arrangements based on adequate cost recovery from
            beneficiaries; (c) feeder road rehabilitation and
            maintenance; and (d) technical assistance and training.
